qas.question: During 6000 BC what area was occupied by a Neolithic culture?
What culture succeeded the Naqada culture?
When is the earliest hieroglyghics date back?
How long did cultures coexist in lower Egypt?

context: By about 6000 BC, a Neolithic culture rooted in the <a0_0>Nile Valley<a0_0/>. During the Neolithic era, several predynastic cultures developed independently in Upper and Lower Egypt. The <a1_0>Badarian culture<a1_0/> and the successor Naqada series are generally regarded as precursors to dynastic Egypt. The earliest known Lower Egyptian site, Merimda, predates the Badarian by about seven hundred years. Contemporaneous Lower Egyptian communities coexisted with their southern counterparts for <a3_0>more than two thousand years<a3_0/>, remaining culturally distinct, but maintaining frequent contact through trade. The earliest known evidence of Egyptian hieroglyphic inscriptions appeared during the predynastic period on Naqada III pottery vessels, dated to about <a2_0>3200 BC<a2_0/>.
